channel.title: General on Nathan R. Yergler
channel.description: Recent content in General on Nathan R. Yergler

item.title: Muni to Run… Windows !?!
item.description: As seen on SFist , SF MTA is asking for $300,000 to update the ATCS (Advanced Train Control System) — the software which runs the subway — to Windows.

item.title: Technology Summit
item.description: Yesterday was the first ever Creative Commons Technology Summit , hosted at Google.

item.title: Getting Things Zero’d
item.description: I really love task lists — especially the crossing off part — but lately they haven’t really been helping me out.

item.title: Friend Devaluation
item.description: I can’t take credit for finding it — that goes to Matt — but this video is a hilarious take on Facebook in real life.

item.title: Web 2.0…
item.description: Struggle as you may to define Web 2.

item.title: Licenses for Blogs
item.description: John Palfrey of the Berkman Center wrote a post proposing licenses specifically for blogs and feeds, based on Creative Commons licenses.

item.title: Now with Vitamin K2
item.description: So I’m using K2 on TLOA now… we’ll see how it goes.

item.title: FSM, right here in Indiana
item.description: I was just looking at the Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster , and imagine my surprise (or lack there of, in retrospect) when I saw my childhood school on the list of CC’d school boards: Bluffton-Harrison Metropolitan Schools .

item.title: Snow!
item.description: It’s Snow!

item.title: Continued Craziness
item.description: Last project due today and then perhaps the sleep deprivation will stop.

item.title: Just a little crazy
item.description: So I’m sitting at the coffee shop, up since 4 AM, more than a little sleep deprived working on finishing my software engineering presentation for this morning.

item.title: One Minute
item.description: Stop, take a minute, and reflect .

item.title: Cold, Hard Cash
item.description: So I saw two movies over the past two days, both “bio-pics” and both quite good in their own way.

item.title: Custom Log Formats with Squid
item.description: [The first in a series of posts to help me (and hopefully others) remember how to get `Zope http://zope.

item.title: A matter of perspective, I guess
item.description: Joel relates an interesting way to look at the big boys of tech:

item.title: There goes my VC funding
item.description: So I just saw a story reporting that Palm is replacing the SIM tray for Treo 650 users.

item.title: Here Fishy, Fishy
item.description: full size Without a flash, and through a lousy disposable camera view finder, this is one of the better underwater photos from our snorkeling trip.

item.title: Happy New Year (and once again, where have I been?)
item.description: I rang in the New Year with friends in Milwaukee.

item.title: Hail to the Chief
item.description: BoingBoing has an amusing story about the latest sign of our esteemed chairmen’s growing influence: he has his own meme.

item.title: Creative Commons support in Gnome
item.description: After reading about the new Nautilus-Python bindings, I decided I had to try my hand.

item.description: Browsing around craigslist , and I run into this .

item.title: ccV 1.5.0 Available
item.description: If anyone wants to hack on the validator source code, I’ve just released a new distribution, reflecting the changes now in place at validator.

item.title: 5 Reasons Canada is Paradise
item.description: Garrett and I spent last weekend in Toronto for Toronto Pride.

item.title: Updated Tagger
item.description: Just a quick note that I’ve uploaded new builds of ccTag, a set of graphical and command-line tools for embedding Creative Commons license claims in MP3 files.

item.title: The 30 Second Commons
item.description: With my recent work on ccValidator and mozCC , I’ve been faced with the challenge of communicating about my work to lay-people (my parents, siblings, therapist, partner, etc).

item.title: Creative Commons Technology Challenge
item.description: The Creative Commons posted some “technology challenges” yesterday.
